title: NML 1682 - First implementation of PoET consensus module with new architecture
body:
This puts a stake in the ground with respect to the PoET consensus module in the new and improved architecture.  Specifically it:
* Uses pre-canned sealed signup information for the genesis block until the genesis utility seeds the chain with signup information for the initial validator
* Each validator creates signup information and registers it with the validator registry.  This is done every time the validator starts up.  Once consensus state is implemented, the sealed signup data will be persisted across invocations so that a validator may reconstitute the PoET enclave.
* Creates wait timers and wait certificates appropriately during initialize_block and finalize_block, respectively.
* The block verifier will automatically allow blocks to pass until there is at least one validator in the validator registry.  This will remain in effect until the genesis utility seeds the genesis block with the initial validator signup information.
* The block verifier currently ignores the wait certificate's check_valid results because of a race condition in the updating of the block chain resulting in incorrect local means being calculated for the wait timers (and therefore resulting wait certificates).
* A PoET enclave factory was added because the consensus object is no longer long-lived and need a way to implement singleton pattern for PoET enclaves as there should ever only be one running and it should not be continuously shut down and brought up.
* All PoET objects (SignupInfo, WaitTimer, and WaitCertificate) have been updated to accept a PoET enclave module for all methods that need it instead of keeping a class variable.

This version does not:
* Do proper fork resolution - it always just chooses the fork with the chain head with the highest block number.
* Implement the C, K, and zTest policies as that requires that consensus state be implemented.

To test, start up both the config and validator registry transaction processors (assuming starting in sawtooth-core):

`./bin/tp_config -v tcp://localhost:40000`
`./bin/tp_validator_registry -v tcp://localhost:40000`

Create a configuration transaction to set the consensus algorithm to PoET, create the genesis block, and start the validator:

`rm ~/sawtooth/data/*`
`./bin/sawtooth keygen`
`./bin/sawtooth config set -k <key_file_just_created> sawtooth.consensus.algorithm=poet sawtooth.poet.target_wait_time=5 sawtooth.poet.minimum_wait_time=1`
`./bin/sawtooth admin genesis config.batch`
`./bin/validator -vv`

The run_docker_test script is modified for not stopping until the test container exits, so that other containers can exit which should be orchestrated by the test container.

title: Rearrange Setting Subcommands and add `settings list`
body:
The sawtooth config subcommands are rearranged into meaningful subgroups,`proposal` and `settings`.

The `proposal` subcommand group, is made up of the `create` subcommand. This takes the place of the `set` and `propose` commands by combining them into one operation, which either records a file or submits the settings to the validator.

The `settings` subcommand group is made up (currently) of the `list` subcommand. This command displays the list of current on-chain settings, read from a validator's REST api.  The settings may be outputed as key/value text (the default), CSV, JSON or YAML.


Additionally:

- Corrects an issue with the rest api not returning empty fields from protobuf objects.

title: Chain controller and block validator tests
Add block and batch request messages
body:
The best way to test that this works (since we do not have network tests yet) is the following. You will see one validator create the genesis block. When you start loading transaction the non-genesis validator will not process any blocks and will send out a GossipBlockRequest message. Once it recives the genesis block, you will see it start processing batches. Currently, for this to work the validators need to be peered in both directions and they will continue to send batches back and forth forever. 

In terminal:
sawtooth admin genesis
validator -vv --peers tcp://0.0.0.0:8801

In new terminal:
validator --network-endpoint tcp://0.0.0.0:8801 --component-endpoint tcp://0.0.0.0:40001 --peers tcp://0.0.0.0:8800 -vv

In new terminal:
tp_intkey_python tcp://localhost:40000 -vv

In new terminal:
tp_intkey_python tcp://localhost:40001 -vv

Finally: 
intkey populate
intkey load

title: Determine and use Consensus Module using On-chain Settings
body:
During genesis block construction, the consensus module can be loaded based on the settings supplied by the sawtooth_config transaction family.  The module is then used to correctly initialize and finalize the block before committing it to the block store.

The consensus module is also before it is used during Journal's processing of blocks.

title: Rest api restart
body:
Previously it was possible to restart the rest api without restarting the validator. Then it was possible to restart the validator without restarting the rest api, but not while the rest api was waiting for a response from the validator. This PR makes it possible to restart the validator while the rest api is waiting for a response. It will return a 503 Service Unavailable. 

This PR also fixes similar behavior in the intkey load cli, where if the validator stopped before returning responses to all messages an uncaught error would happen. This PR catches that error and logs a message.

title: Implement executor support for TP list from config txn family
body:
To require a transaction processor, sawtooth config --key your-key 'sawtooth.validator.transaction_families=[{"family": "intkey", "version": "1.0", "encoding":"application/cbor"}]', and then either "intkey load -f config.batch" on an already running validator or give the config.batch file to the genesis util: sawtooth admin genesis config.batch, and then start the validator.

If there are no required transaction processors, the executor will wait for transaction processors for all transactions (This is useful on startup). If there are required transaction processors and a transaction comes in that is not on the list, the Executor will immediately fail it.

Also, the hard-coded "tcp://" is removed from the Stream python class as we might want to support other transport protocols. Then main modules used in bins are updated to specify tcp, as well as docker files and the docker manage library.

title: Add State Views and Config View specialization
body:
**Add StateView and its Factory**

StateViewFactory provides read-only views into state stored in a merkle tree database. These views can provide a window into the state which can be used throughout a block of processing without concern of the state being changed underneath the process.

**Add ConfigView and its Factory**

ConfigView is a specialized StateView which translates keys into state addresses and transforms state entries into their respective values. This can be used by validator components to read on-chain settings at viewed from the lens of a specific point in the chain.

title: Refactor Interconnect zeromq interface and dispatcher
body: The dispatcher is asynchronous but sequential for any given message. Define Handler implementations and then add them to the dispatcher. For a message that comes in that is not a response, the handlers are run in order asynchronously, with the possibility that any given handler can fail the message and the message is dropped. This could be for signature verification, for example. An implementation detail that seems to be an improvement is that when you add the handler you get to pick the concurrent.futures.Executor instance to run that handler in. For signature verification I have chosen a ProcessPoolExecutor with 3 processes, which speeds up signature verification.

title: Remove Quorum
body:
Signed-off-by: nickdrozd <drozd@bitwise.io>

Code relating to quorum has been removed, but the documentation still needs to be updated. For instance, the Introduction has this paragraph:
"Sawtooth Lake abstracts the core concepts of consensus, isolates consensus from transaction semantics, and provides two consensus protocols with different performance trade-offs. The first, called PoET for “Proof of Elapsed Time”, is a lottery protocol that builds on trusted execution environments (TEEs) provided by Intel’s SGX to address the needs of large populations of participants. The second, Quorum Voting, is an adaptation of the Ripple and Stellar consensus protocols and serves to address the needs of applications that require immediate transaction finality."

title: install_requires as the one place for requirements
body:
Merge the different places where Python dependencies are specified
into one (DRY) place. This should make it easier to maintain the list
since there is only one place where they are specified.

The different Sawtooth packages should now correctly specify their own dependencies
which means that with this patch using `pip install -e .` or `python setup.py
develop` should also work correctly.

For example using the following `requirements.txt` placed in `sawtooth-core` as `requirements-dev-venv.txt`:

```
-e core/
-e validator/
-e extensions/mktplace
-e extensions/arcade
```

Sawtooth will install in a virtualenv on OSX.

```
$ virtualenv venv
$ source venv/bin/activate
$ pip install -r requirements-dev-venv.txt
```

Passing the tests

```
$ cd core
$ nose2
...

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 121 tests in 45.751s

OK
---------- coverage: platform darwin, python 2.7.12-final-0 ----------
Coverage HTML written to dir htmlcov
$ cd ../validator
$ nose2

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 34 tests in 249.776s

OK (skipped=10)
---------- coverage: platform darwin, python 2.7.12-final-0 ----------
Coverage HTML written to dir htmlcov

$ cd ../extensions/mktplace
$ nose2
...
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 30 tests in 0.011s

OK (skipped=10)
---------- coverage: platform darwin, python 2.7.12-final-0 ----------
Coverage HTML written to dir htmlcov
```
